title: 'Why War?': How thinkers answer this heartbreaking question
subhead: Since the bloodbath of World War I, philosophers have repeatedly grappled with the question: Is war an irrepressible human urge, or the product of historical and social forces?

title: Europe will 'stand united' in response to Trump's tariff threats over Greenland
Wildfires in Chile kill at least 15, force 50,000 to evacuate in the south
As Iranians face repression, 'inaction amounts to passive complicity'
subhead: What is taking place in Iran today is no longer a sporadic crackdown, but a massacre, warn nearly 200 figures from the cultural sphere.

title: Syria's leader agrees truce deal with Kurds after government troops advance
subhead: The agreement, which includes a ceasefire, will see the Kurdish administration and forces integrate into the state. It comes after deadly clashes in the Syrian city of Raqa on Sunday between Kurdish-led forces and local fighters loyal to Damascus.

title: New York rapper A$AP Rocky makes comeback in new album, balancing fury and serenity
subhead: After an eight-year wait, the artist – and Rihanna's partner – has released his fourth album, 'Don't Be Dumb.' The varied and accomplished record features collaborations with Tim Burton, Tyler, The Creator, Doechii and Damon Albarn.

title: The meteoric rise of Arthur Mensch, France's AI champion
subhead: In less than three years, the co-founder and head of the young French start-up Mistral AI has become a leading figure in the rapid rise of artificial intelligence worldwide.

'That 'Stranger Things' brings Prince or David Bowie back to life is both wonderful and dreadful'
subhead: In the final episode of the hit Netflix series, 15- to 25-year-olds discovered 'Purple Rain' and 'Heroes,' whose streams have soared across music platforms. Unfortunately, the younger generation has limited itself to these snippets, showing little interest in the artists or their discographies, writes Michel Guerrin, editor-in-chief of Le Monde, in his column.

title: How a uranium supply coveted by Russia ended up in limbo in Niger
subhead: A convoy of trucks loaded with 1,000 metric tons of uranium concentrate left the Arlit mine in Niger on November 27. The shipment was supposed to reach the port of Lomé, Togo, for transfer to a Russian bulk carrier, according to French government sources. Instead, it got stuck at Niamey airport.

title: In Libya's desert, Sudanese refugees cross paths as they flee or return to their homeland
subhead: Between 350,000 and one million Sudanese refugees have arrived in Libya since the outbreak of war in April 2023. In the southern city of Kufra, refugees end up in unsanitary camps. With no prospects, some decide to return to Sudan, despite the horrors of the fighting.
